I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been assisting the Government of Mongolia 
(the Government) to restructure its education system. During the Country Program Mission in 
2002, the Government asked ADB to provide technical assistance (TA) for preparing the Third 
Education Development Project (TEDP). A fact-finding mission visited Mongolia in November 
2003  and  agreed  with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  scope,  implementation  and  financing 
arrangements, cost estimates and the consultants’ terms of reference.1 Following elections and 
change of Government, a confirmation mission was fielded in September 2004 to reconfirm the  
TA  concept  and  to  adjust  and  update  the  TA’s  outputs,  implementation  and  financing 
arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since termination of financial and technical support from the former Soviet Union in 
1991,  the  quality  of  and  access  to  the  education  services  in  Mongolia  has  deteriorated. 
Mongolia had earlier achieved universal primary education, but following a sharp drop in the 
enrollment rate, re-attaining is a priority objective. The Government has prioritized education in 
national development and allocated considerable state expenditure to the sector, even during a 
severe  economic  recession.  However,  expenditure  on  education  has  reached  a  ceiling, 
averaging about 20% of total Government expenditures in 2000–2002. More than 70% of the 
education budget is allocated to personnel salaries and heating costs. 
 
3.  Financial constraints have exacerbated the numerous problems in the education sector: 
(i) delays in updating the content of education to be responsive to the needs in the market 
economy, (ii) limited capacities of the Ministry of Education, Science, and Culture (MOECS) and 
local education authorities, (iii) high demand for new construction and rehabilitation of school 
facilities, and the related problem of insufficient maintenance, (iv) lack of effective instructional 
materials, (v) irrelevant and outmoded technical education and vocational training (TEVT), (vi) 
resistance  to  introduction  of  cost-recovery  schemes  for  public  universities,  (vii)  limited 
involvement of the private sector in TEVT and higher education, and (viii) uneven budget 
allocations  among  subsectors.  Most  seriously,  the  widening  gap  in  learning  environments 
between urban and rural areas has greatly contributed to large-scale internal migration. The 
poverty reduction strategy paper (PRSP)2 and country strategy and program update3 have 
pointed out that internal migration is the biggest obstacle to reducing poverty. Many rural 
parents see education as an investment in bettering the life of their children and move to urban 
areas  for  quality  schooling.  The  dearth  of  qualified  teachers  in  rural  schools  accelerates 
migration to cities, where many schools are already too crowded. These migrants often join the 
urban poor. 
 
4.  ADB has been the major provider of assistance in the education sector since 1990. The 
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Nordic Development Fund (NDF), and United 
Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) also provide assistance to basic education; the European 
Union, Korea International Cooperation Agency, and Soros Foundation to secondary and higher 
education; and the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), 
and UNICEF to early child care and education and nonformal education.

2  
5.  In  1996,  ADB  approved  the  Education  Sector  Development  Program  (ESDP),4  an 
integrated package including a policy reform program, investment project, and associated TA. 
The ESDP’s objective was to improve financial sustainability and upgrade educational facilities 
by reducing redundant staff and rehabilitating school buildings. The program also promoted a 
cost-sharing system for textbook printing and distribution, privatization of state universities, and 
private sector involvement in TEVT and higher education. Based on the achievements of the 
ESDP, which was successfully completed in 2002, the Government prepared a comprehensive 
education sector strategy (ESS) for 2001–2005, to improve access to basic education. The 
Government requested ADB for continued support through the Second Education Development 
Project (SEDP) approved in 2002.5 The SEDP, which is cofinanced by NDF, focuses on (i) 
school  rehabilitation,  (ii)  provision  of  instructional  materials,  and  (iii)  capacity  building  of 
schoolteachers and administrators. Under the ESDP and SEDP, significant progress has been 
made: 181 schools were successfully restructured under the ESDP, improving the efficiency of 
education delivery and stabilizing education finance, and about 66 schools and kindergartens 
are being rehabilitated under the SEDP. 
 
6.  With  the  Government’s  continued  commitment  and  extensive  external  assistance, 
significant progress has been made in restructuring the education sector. Enrollment in basic 
education  is  recovering,  the  national  curriculum  and  standards  have  been  updated,  and 
teachers’ average qualifications have been upgraded. However, further actions and reforms are 
urgently needed to address geographical inequities in learning environments and sub–sectors 
other than basic education. One of the key issues to be resolved is the lack of an effective donor 
coordination mechanism. The Government prepared the ongoing ESS assisted only by ADB; 
other donors’ inputs were limited and focused mainly on project activities rather than the overall 
policy dialogue with the Government. Under the ESS, a common understanding on priority 
targeting of sub–sectors and areas among donors is missing. The Government has requested 
support from ADB to jointly prepare a new ESS for 2006–2010 to serve as a framework for more 
substantial  donor  coordination.  The  new  ESS  will  address  all  sub–sectors  and  promote 
education  reforms  to  improve  the  quality  of  and  access  to  rural  education  services. 
Complementing the formal education system, strategies will be developed to provide lifelong 
learning and training opportunities for youth and adults. The new ESS will also encourage 
public-private partnership in education. 
 
7.  To improve access to education, the Government, supported by donors, is implementing 
a school restructuring and rehabilitation program. However, due to limited resources, most rural 
schools have not yet benefited from rehabilitation measures. Large-scale internal migration to 
urban centers has increased the pressure on urban schools to maintain adequate education 
quality standards. The new Government has decided to extend the current 10-year education 
system to an 11-year system and is considering introducing a 12-year system soon. This 
extension of the schooling period by 1–2 years needs to be reflected in future rehabilitation 
plans and will require additional capacities and new learning and teaching materials. To resolve 
issues posed by inadequate educational facilities and to upgrade capacities to extend the 
schooling period, the Government has requested ADB to provide further assistance to identify 
and prioritize investment needs to be financed under the proposed loan project. 
 
8.  The lack of a systematic in-service training mechanism for teachers has been identified 
as  a  constraint  on  the  reform  process.  The  SEDP  supports  MOECS’s  efforts  to  improve 
didactics,  promote  a  pupil-centered  learning  environment,  and  introduce  information  and

communication  technology  to  support  teaching  and  learning  aids.  However,  no  systematic 
teacher training mechanism to address challenges anticipated with the proposed introduction of 
an 11- or 12–year system is yet in place. Taking into account that many rural schools provide 
only 6 or 8 grades, the Government is anticipating difficulties implementing the 11-12 grade 
system countrywide. The TA will identify investment needs to strengthen pre-service and in-
service teacher training to meet the new challenges. 
 
9.  With support from the ESDP, the Government has privatized several state universities 
and developed an accreditation system for quality control of private universities. However, the 
state expenditure on higher education is still a heavy burden, and there are too many public 
universities for the small population. The Government continues to support the subsector in 
various forms, including subsidies, scholarships for civil servants’ families, and tax exemptions. 
The TA will help the Government plan the reform of higher education by developing strategies to 
be incorporated in the new ESS 2006–2010. 
 
10.  The Government enacted a decree to encourage the private sector to become involved 
in TEVT. Subsequently, the Government reduced its role in this subsector and reduced public 
support to secondary vocational schools. However, few private companies will or can support 
TEVT. As a result, TEVT has been one of most neglected areas of education. No systematic 
mechanism matches training provision with labor market demand. Most vocational schools use 
outdated equipment and curricula that were developed during the Soviet period. The demand 
for skilled labor is growing, particularly in urban areas, but no mechanism offers skills training for 
youths and adults responding to the demand. The TEVT system must be reviewed and the 
future role of the Government in the subsector defined. The TA will help the Government 
consolidate  the  existing  TEVT  system  and  recommend  strategies  to  establish  a  flexible 
demand–driven system, to create lifelong training opportunities for youth and adults, enhance 
participation by industry, propose alternative financing mechanisms to promote skills training, 
and identify priority investment needs to support the proposed changes.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  In line with the ESS and the Millennium Development Goals, the overall goal of the TA is 
to improve access to and quality of education services for children and increase skills training 
opportunities for youth and adults. In line with the country strategy and program, the TA will 
explore the possibility of taking a sector-wide approach to coordinate government and externally 
supported activities in the education sector. Building on the achievements of the ESDP and 
ongoing SEDP, the proposed project will particularly address priority needs in basic education 
and review the scope for consolidating the TEVT system. The expected TA outputs are (i) a 
draft  ESS  for  2006–2010,  including  a  donor  coordination  mechanism  and  a  prioritized 
investment plan; (ii) draft strategies to align organizational structures, operational procedures, 
human resources (HR) management systems, and financial and HR requirements with the new 
ESS developed for MOECS, relevant aimag (provincial) authorities, schools, teachers’ training 
colleges, and universities; (iii) a prioritized rehabilitation plan for further rehabilitation of school 
facilities; and (iv) draft strategies and investment needs to introduce a flexible, market-oriented 
TEVT  system  to  create  lifelong  learning  opportunities;  and  (v)  a  loan  project  proposal, 
incorporating priority needs identified in (i) – (iv).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be conducted in a collaborative and participatory process ensuring a high 
level of congruence of goals between all major government and nongovernment stakeholders,

4  
and the development partners. At the end of the implementation period, a participatory planning 
workshop with all major stakeholders will discuss findings and recommendations and agree on 
the design of the proposed new loan project. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  Output 1. Building on the achievements of the ESS 2000–2005 a draft ESS for 2006– 
2010 addressing all subsectors will be developed. The new ESS will include strategies to 
promote the education reform process, establish a lifelong learning system for youth and adults, 
and set up an effective and efficient donor coordination mechanism and will also provide an 
inventory of the future investments. The new ESS will be formulated in close collaboration with 
all major government and nongovernment stakeholders and donors. Major activities under this 
output include (i) reviewing the progress and achievements of the current ESS and identifying 
issues, and (ii) preparing a draft ESS 2006–2010 addressing all subsectors. 
 
14.  Output 2. To align organizational structures, operational procedures, HR management 
systems, and financial and HR requirements with the new ESS 2006–2010, current institutional 
capacities will be assessed and institutional arrangements between MOECS relevant aimag and 
soum  (district)  authorities,  schools  and  public  training  institutions  reviewed.  Based  on  the 
review, capacity-building strategies, including HR development plans, will be prepared. The 
review will assess education financing, teachers’ salary structure, and financial management of 
schools, and address the need to strengthen sector performance monitoring. 
 
15.  Output 3. A prioritized plan including detailed cost estimates for further rehabilitation of 
kindergarten, school, and college facilities will be prepared to complement the rehabilitation 
program implemented under the SEDP. The plan will include strategies for ensuring community 
participation in rehabilitation and operation and maintenance (O&M) of schools. Major activities 
will be to (i) update the school mapping study; (ii) analyze the financial resources required for 
O&M of rehabilitated facilities; (iii) propose strategies to involve communities, students, and 
teachers in rehabilitating and maintaining facilities; and (iv) propose appropriate technologies 
and materials for heating systems. 
 
16.   Output 4. This component will clarify Government’s future role in providing TEVT. 
Strategies will be developed to consolidate the current TEVT system and promote a flexible, 
demand-driven,  cost-effective  system  offering  lifelong  training  opportunities  for  youths  and 
adults. Recommendations will be made to (i) enhance private sector involvement, (ii) consider 
alternative financial mechanisms to make more skills training programs available, and (iii) build 
capacities for analyzing labor market trends and skills in demand. 
 
17.       Output 5. A loan project proposal will be prepared, focusing on priority areas agreed on 
with the Government: school rehabilitation, teaching and learning materials, new needs arising 
from extending the schooling period by 1–2 years, and a flexible, demand-driven TEVT system. 
The proposal will incorporate the outcomes of outputs 1–4 and include sector, economic and 
institutional analysis, and detailed costing and implementation arrangements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA cost is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 is the foreign 
exchange cost and $225,000 equivalent the local currency cost. The Government requests ADB 
to finance $500,000 equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange cost and $100,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the remaining local currency 
cost of $125,000 equivalent in kind. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government has been advised that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. Cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOECS will be the TA’s Executing Agency and will provide suitable furnished office 
space and counterpart support, including a qualified TA coordinator acceptable to ADB to 
oversee TA implementation. Under the TA coordinator a consultant team will be established, 
consisting of (i) seven international consultants: (a) education policy specialist and policy team 
leader (4.5 person-months), (b) education economist and organizational development specialist 
(3.0  person-months),  (c)  education  facilities  specialist  (2.0  person-months),  (d)  education 
information  management  specialist  (1.5  person-month),  (e)  TVET  specialist  (3.0  person-
months),  (f)  training  specialist  (2.5  person-months),  and  (g)  participatory  project  planning 
specialist (0.5 person month); and (ii) three domestic consultants: (a) education policy analyst 
(4.0 person-months), (b) financial analyst (4.0 person-months), and (c) maintenance specialist 
(2.0  person-months).  The  team  leader  will  submit  an  inception  report  4  weeks  after  the 
assignment starts, a draft final report 2 weeks before, and a final report 2 weeks after the 
participatory planning workshop.   
 
20.  A steering committee, chaired by the vice minister of MOECS, will be established to 
provide policy guidance and to help MOECS coordinate with all stakeholders. A joint advisory 
body comprising government and nongovernment stakeholders and donor representatives will 
be  established  to  provide  technical  advice  in  the  process  of  drafting  the  new  ESS  and 
developing  a  donor  coordination  mechanism.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  5  months 
commencing  in  February  2005.  At  the  end  of  the  implementation  period,  a  participatory 
workshop involving major government and nongovernment stakeholders and donors will be 
conducted to present the findings of the TA and to agree on the concept for the TEDP. The 
consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. An international consulting firm will be selected based on the quality- and cost-
based selection method, using the simplified technical proposal. Outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 3. TA-financed equipment and materials will be procured either 
by consultants or ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Mongolia  for  preparing  the  Third  Education  Development  Project,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented by a team of seven international and 
three domestic consultants.  
 
A.       Specific Tasks and Responsibilities of International Consultants 
 
2.    Education Policy Specialist and Policy Team Leader (4.5 person-months). As team 
leader, the consultant will be responsible for the overall planning and implementation of the TA, 
design  of  the  loan  project,  and  preparation  of  reports.  The  work  will  be  done  in  close 
collaboration with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (MOECS) and in consultation 
with senior staff members of other relevant government and nongovernment organizations, local 
authorities  involved  in  education,  training  providers,  community-based  schools, and  private 
sector  representatives.  The  team  leader  will  ensure  close  collaboration  among  the  other 
consultants with the following specific duties and responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Determine the scope of, and prepare a detailed outline for, the proposed loan 
project and assess the feasibility of the project for investment. 
(ii)  Develop  a  draft  logical  framework  for  the  project,  including  goal,  purpose, 
outputs,  activities  and  inputs,  performance  indicators  and  targets,  monitoring 
mechanisms, and assumptions and risks, in cooperation with the TA team.  
(iii)  Prepare detailed cost estimates, subdivided into foreign and local costs. 
(iv)  Define project implementation arrangements, outline the relationship between 
relevant institutions, and indicate the responsibility of each.  
(v)  Produce a tentative procurement plan for goods and services. 
(vi)  Evaluate the financial and economic viability of the project.  
(vii)  Submit (a) an inception report 4 weeks after the assignment starts, and (b) a 
draft final report 2 weeks before and a final report 2 weeks after the participatory 
planning workshop. 
 
3.       Major duties and responsibilities with regard to education policy are as follows:  
(i)  Review and assess the progress and achievements of the education reform 
process against the policy targets set out in the education sector strategy (ESS) 
2001–2005 and the Millennium Development Goals and identify the issues to be 
addressed in all subsectors.  
(ii)  Assess the demand for education services, including youth and adults, based on 
demographic trends, economic development, and migration trends. 
(iii)  Review the current policies on and performance of aimag (provincial) center 
schools,  Complex  schools,1  Pedagogical  University,  and  five  local  teachers’ 
colleges, and identify capacity-building needs. 
(iv)  Review lessons learned from Complex schools. 
(v)  Document all donor activities and assess their outputs and achievements. 
(vi)  Prepare a nongovernment organization (NGO) directory, including education and 
training activities promoted by NGOs. 
(vii)  Propose a more effective coordination mechanism among government agencies, 
donors, NGOs, and the private sector. 
(viii)  Review and assess current policy and progress and interim outputs of transfer to 
an 11-year education system.  
(ix)  Conduct comparative studies on international experience and recommend new 
trends of developing content and standards for a 12-year education system.

training systems to meet modern standards and needs. 
(xi)  Review  and  assess  current  policies  and  mechanisms  for  writing,  publishing, 
distributing, and using textbooks and project further trends. 
(xii)  Determine priorities for improving quality of higher education in collaboration with

(xiii)  Prepare a draft ESS 2006–2010 addressing all subsectors and strategies to 
establish a lifelong learning system for youth and adults, and an inventory of

(xiv)  Prepare strategies to establish a donor coordination mechanism. 
 
4.       Education Economist and Organizational Development Specialist (3.0 person-
months). In close cooperation with the team leader, the consultant will prepare an economic 
analysis of the proposed loan project and the poverty and social analysis according to Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) requirements. In addition, the consultant’s major specific duties and 
responsibilities are as follows:  
 
(i)  Review the education financing, estimate financial requirements in line with the 
proposed  ESS  2006–2010,  review  budget  projections,  and  teachers’  salary 
structure. 
(ii)  Assess budgeting procedures and flow of funds from national to local level. 
(iii)  Examine the possibility of introducing a matching system of education budgets 
for local education authorities and recommend roles and responsibilities for local 
authorities promoting education. 
(iv)  Review the management structure and capacities of MOECS, aimag education 
centers, regional teachers’ colleges, universities, and selected Complex schools, 
and propose management training programs. 
(v)  Evaluate alternatives for financing higher education and technical education and 
vocational training (TEVT) by government, private sector, and NGOs, including 
sustainability issues. 
(vi)  Recommend  capacity-building  measures  and  identify  training  needs  at  all 
relevant levels. 
 
5.       Education Facilities Specialist (2.0 person-months). The specialist will closely work with 
the domestic maintenance consultants and architects deployed under the Second Education 
Development Project (SEDP), who will provide all necessary information and support. Major 
tasks are as follows:

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Mongolia: 
 
Promotion of education is one of the development priorities of the Government to reduce poverty. The Government is 
committed to improving access to and quality of education. The project will help reduce poverty by increasing access 
to basic education services, particularly in remote rural areas where about 33% of the populace live below the poverty 
line. By making skills training easily available, the project will give migrant and poor communities in urban areas better 
opportunities to earn income and improve their livelihoods.   
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The analysis will do the following:   
(i)  identify how the project relates to national priorities defined in the country poverty analysis; 
(ii)  assess needs and constraints of poor urban migrants and ethnic minority groups; 
(iii)  assess the effects of the ensuing project on its beneficiaries, especially socioeconomic benefits and  
impact on income levels; and 
(iv)  identify poverty-related baselines for project monitoring and evaluation.

between all major government and nongovernment stakeholders and the development partners. At the end of the

findings and recommendations and to agree on the design of the proposed new loan project.
